text: Traveling - it leaves you speechless, then turns you into a storyteller.
author: Ibn Battuta

text: Travel changes you. As you move through this life and this world you change things slightly, you leave marks behind, however small. And in return, life - and travel - leaves marks on you. Most of the time, those marks - on your body or on your heart - are beautiful. Often, though, they hurt.
author: Anthony Bourdain

text: Travellers, like poets, are mostly an angry race.
author: Richard Francis Burton

text:
I depart, 
 Whither I know not; but the hour's gone by 
 When Albion's lessening shores could grieve or glad mine eye.
author: Lord Byron

text:
In travelling 
 I shape myself betimes to idleness 
 And take fools' pleasure.
author: George Eliot

text: Though we travel the world over to find the beautiful, we must carry it with us or we find it not.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

text: I have been a stranger in a strange land.
author: Exodus, II. 22

text: Let him go abroad to a distant country; let him go to some place where he is not known. Don't let him go to the devil where he is known.
author: Samuel Johnson

text: Though they carry nothing forth with them, yet in all their journey they lack nothing. For wheresoever they come, they be at home.
author: Sir Thomas More

text: A man of ordinary talent will always be ordinary, whether he travels or not: but a man of superior talent will go to pieces if he remains forever in the same place...
author: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

text: When I was at home, I was in a better place; but travellers must be content.
author: William Shakespeare

text:
And in his brain, 
 Which is as dry as the remainder biscuit 
 After a voyage, he hath strange places cramm'd 
 With observation, the which he vents 
 In mangled forms.
author: William Shakespeare

text: All journeys end in disappointment if for no other reason than that they end.
author: Lucius Shepard

text: A rolling stone gathers no moss.
author: Publius Syrus

text:
One who journeying 
 Along a way he knows not, having crossed 
 A place of drear extent, before him sees 
 A river rushing swiftly toward the deep, 
 And all its tossing current white with foam, 
 And stops and turns, and measures back his way.
author: Homer, The Iliad

text:
I am fevered with the sunset, 
 I am fretful with the bay, 
 For the wander-thirst is on me 
 And my soul is in Cathay.
author: Richard Hovey

text:
Down to Gehenna or up to the throne, 
 He travels the fastest who travels alone.
author: Rudyard Kipling

text:
For always roaming with a hungry heart, 
 Much have I seen and known.
author: Alfred Tennyson
